summary: A Great Baseball Game, With Little Flaws (8.5 out of 10 on point scale)
reviewText: I should let the readers of this review know something before getting started: I am not a huge sports fan (in terms of gaming). I never really cared for the Madden franchise (I do plan on trying Madden 25 again, but to be honest that game disappointing me last I played it), I have never played FIFA, NHL, MLB, and 2K franchises, really relying on the NCAA football games for my sports needs in gaming. I am a lover of platformers, of shooters, of RPGs, of all games really, but the one section of gaming I never got too deep into was sports games. Well, I think I might be changing that soon, at least when it comes to the MLB: The Show series.Going into this title, I had no clue how to play a baseball game, and yet this game give much to a beginner to be able to play decently quickly. Batting can be a little tough, but once you get use to the specific styles of pitching and where the batters box is, it gets a little easier. Pitching is fantastic, making me feel like a god on the mound most times. Personally, I loved pitching most of all in this game, but really the game plays extremely well, realistically, and very fun. Overall, the gameplay in this title is solid, fun, and easy to learn, hard to master (which makes for a great challenge).The animations, graphics, and looks in the game are also another huge plus. The game looks fantastic; blades of grass, the individual stadiums, and so on all look amazing. Each player has been modeled almost to a T, looking almost exactly like their real life selves, and they nailed how each pitcher, batter, and player operates when it comes to their personal styles. The uniforms look great, the bats and gloves look detailed, and the attendants in the stadiums are actually quite detailed and look like separate people (most times) from one another, and have fun animations to see.After playing with the Franchise mode and the Road to the Show mode, I can easily say the Road portion of this title is the best of the game. Not only do you create your own character, but you create your ideal perfect player to watch. It is fun, exhillerating, and can be frustrating (in a good way) when trying to make the best of the best possible. The Franchise mode is also quite fun, but it is just like most other sports games I suppose when coming to a Dynasty mode.This game is fantastic and fun, and I personally loved it, but it isn't without flaws.This game has issues with loading times. I mean, the loading times were long enough to where I could go take out the garbage and come back in time to play, or go to the bathroom. They were long (not horribly long, but long enough to be boring and annoying after a point). I often wonder if there could be a means to make the load times better (not so much eliminate them as much as make the time better used), such as possible film of baseball great moments, or video of developers playing the game and kicking butt so to have the players who are waiting able to watch something that should excite them, such as a Grand Slam video clip or a film clip of a pitcher pulling of a no hitter game. These options could be hard to do, and I understand that, I personally wonder if there are means to making the loading times better by not so much eliminating them, but making them more fun or bearable. Overall, the loading times were not horrible, but they were a major factor the the game not being perfect by any means.My one other complaint is the sound. The game sound amazing in game, with the audio and the announcers being solid, the sound effects are fantastic, and really everything in terms of actually playing is awesome. However, the soundtrack is limited, and gets very repetitive. Don't get me wrong, this is a very small portion of the game to really see in-depth, but it is a noticeable annoyance that I wished the creators would have gotten a few more songs to add variety to the soundtrack that was already great, but needed more breathing room in songs. Also, the game could have used more frequent announcer audio of previous games (I would have liked them to happen almost every other song, I liked the audio but I noticed that they started to repeat a lot as well). This is the only other flaw that bugged me, and it is something that I think could be fixed by patches pretty easily.Overall, I loved playing this game, and despite the long loading times and the frequent loading times, along with the lack of tracks and audio in circulation in the game, this game is a very solid game to play and very enjoyable. I recommend playing this if you are either a baseball fan or interested in trying a sports title that is fun and easy to get into. Enjoy the review, thank you for reading, and let me know if you have questions or concerns that I could address!

summary: Mega Man's final adventure on the NES...
reviewText: Near the end of the NES's reign, Capcom rush-released Mega Man's 6th adventure, which involved a mysterious (actually, NOT-SO, judging by the appearance of the character) businessman that steals the national tournament's champions (a.k.a. the robotmasters) and uses them to take over the world. Mega Man naturally speeds to the rescue, but what may sound like an awesome game turned out to be a mere effort, unfortunately. Read on to see why Mega Man's last adventure on NES was not a "one shot at glory":THE GOODWe get two new Rush adaptors (Power and Jet) that kick major arse. You'll find that using them is ten times more fun than using the acquired boss weapons! The music is also thankfully better (although it DOESN'T TOUCH the first four... get to that in THE BAD) and we get more robotmasters and more Wily stages to bash through. Some of the robotmasters are quite unique, especially Tomahawkman and Yamatoman.THE BADThe storyline is TOO similar to Mega Man 4's, and this game pulls it off to a lesser extent. The "Mr. X" disguise didn't fool me at all. While the music was definitely better than the 5th game's, a lot of it is really odd; it just didn't sound like Mega Man. The graphics were also a letdown from 5's parallax graphics, and even some of the sprites (ex.: Mega Man climbing up looks really funky) look rather static. It's clear that this is the last NES game released (to my knowledge), but I think Capcom could've done better. Another aspect of the game that really bothered me was the simplicity of the stages (and the game's insanely easy difficulty).OVERALLI really am mixed about this game. For the longest time, I really liked this one over 5 because it seemed to be more fun. Now, after judging the two games from today's standpoint, I liked 5 better overall because it was harder, the gameplay was a bit smoother (not to mention Beat was ten times better), and the storyline is among the best in the series. This game has great ideas like the Rush adaptors, the Energy Equalizer (I think that's what it's called), better music, and interesting bosses. So basically, if you mashed the two together, you'd get all the Mega Man qualities. Seriously, though, I think Capcom really rushed this one and it shows... And, so, with strenous decision-making, I'd have to say that 5 is better by a notch. Oh man, this game comes SOOOO close. With that said, this is still a decent game, but I ONLY recommend it to Mega Man fans.

summary: The most beautiful, well developed unfun game I own
reviewText: This is a difficult review to write.  This game has to be one of the most beautiful, well developed and nicely written games I have seen in a long time.  In fact, it is so well developed, you have the option to install HD textures prior to playing the game for enhanced game play.  When the cut scenes come on, the characters dialogue is fantastic and well written.  The game even allows for significant customization of your agent.Unfortunately, among all of these things, unless you are a fan of the series, you probably aren't going to like this game.  I am a pretty avid and experienced gamer.  I have even appreciated some of the games in the Splinter Cell series.  But what this games makes up for in beauty and style, it loses in difficulty.  The game is just too hard.  I played at the medium difficulty and could not get through three missions.  Each mission, I would spend hours attempting to memorize a level and each of the AI's habits and "rules" just to get past them.  It would takes dozens of attempts to make it through a level.  You make one small error, not because you did something stupid, but because you miscalculated how far the AI can see or how dark it is, and you have to restart.  The game truly is draconian...and, ultimately, the game play does not feel rewarding.While experienced Splinter Cell fans or those with a lot of time on their hands may enjoy this, I personally wouldn't recommend this game.

summary: Lightning Returns FFXIII:  Another missed opportunity
reviewText: The entirity of the Final Fantasy XIII series (XIII, XIII-X2 and now Lightning Returns) will ultimately be seen as having some great ideas mixed with infruriating and head scratching decisions in execution.FFXIII had a deep (some would say, convulted) story with interesting plots, however the decision on linearity (i.e. forcing the player for TWENTY HOURS to follow one path before opening up) turned off many players before they could truly enjoy the game.FFXIII-X2 made the story even MORE convulted, if that was even possible, but refined the battle system and added in some Pokemon elements (i.e. monsters to fill the 3rd spot) and some more frustrating ones (i.e. The Hands of Time).  The overreaction to make the WHOLE game open-ended let to an equally frustrating problem, and that was when do I close a gate?  Open one?  Where do I go next?And so, now comples the closure of the trilogy with Lightning Returns: FFXIII.  First, let's talk about the good:- The deepest customization in the series.  With only focusing on Lightning, you choose different pieces of garb/outfits, weapons, shields, etc. to make the ultimate fighter.  You'll be tinkering with everything that you pick up and your schimata to make the most lethal combinations.- Combat is also the most free-flowing in the series.  You always had that "pause" in FFXIII and FFXIII-X2 when switching between Paradigms, none of that here, when you've depleted the AP of one outfit, a quick L1 or R1 puts you to the next one with no interruption, and the ones in the background recharge.  It's a full realization of how great the new ATB could be in the next generation.  Imagine if FFXIII and X-2 had kept it simple and only allowed 3 Paradigms at one time, and developed the same manner of switching.  Those games would have been infinitely more playable.- Debatable to be sure, but the sound/music is again a triumph for the series IMHO.  Now, of course I'm partial to tunes in FFIV, FFVI and FFVII, but there's a lot to love here.And now...the not so good:- Character development.  Which should really read "WHAT character development???".  In 500 years, you would think things would change.  Experiences, memories, etc.  Yet you still have Snow whining about Serah. It's been FIVE HUNDRED YEARS dude.  Don't you think it's time to move on?  And Hope somehow went from young (FFXIII) to adult (FFXIII-X2) back to young again in this game; apparently, there was a fountain of youth between Vahalla and the new location.  The deepness of Sazh that we say in the first two games is gone.  Basically, every major player who makes a cameo in Lightining Returns that was in the first 2 games is a shell of their former selves.  It just smacks me as lazy and a mailing in of a game.- The clock.  Yes, for dramatic tension (as Mr. Torgue would say), but for most it will just come off as a gimmick and really annoying.  You lose AN HOUR if you retreat in battle.  You cannot see all the side quests in one playthrough, no matter how skilled a player you are.  So while we have a more open world now, it's an illusion.  If you don't have everything done when the clock strikes zero, you're whisked to the final battle.  So, as a tip, SAVE OFTEN.  This way you won't have to restart from the beginning and you can go down two or three different paths to see all the side quests.- Leveling up is now done...through the quests!  This isn't the standard "kill guys, get XP, level up" process.  Now, you might say that's a neat, new, novel concept.  However, after the upteenth fetch quest you end up going on, you'll learn to hate this design decision.At the end of the day, I would NOT recommend purchasing this game at full price.  For all the good (some of the best combat, and as good a system as FFIV or FFVI, it does NOT discount all the cons, namely the fetch questing, uneven pacing, lazy story and the constant countdown.

reviewText: I'm going to keep this short as I can, because there are many reviews of this game already.  I'll just bring up the points I think make this game very good, and the ones that made it very bad.Bad:The hit detection on sniper rifles is downright horrible.  With the Dragunov I can regularly settle the chevron reticle on a stationary character, fire, and hit absolutely nothing.  Sometimes twice in a row.  It's embarrassing.  The L96A1 seems to work better, but if you scope in, quickly track a target perfectly, settle your breathing, and fire--even if your cross hairs were perfectly centered--the game might just ignore it.  Treyarch, if you're reading this: FIX IT.  If I aim at someone and shoot, I expect the bullet to hit, not veer off to the side for no reason.  That's idiotic.  The generally cluttered maps also make it harder to effectively use the sniper rifles, considering one can just use an assault rifle in bursts to much the same effect, and be perfectly suited to close quarters as well.However the teams are set up, it's horribly unbalanced.  I always seem to be in games where either my team is completely destroying the other, or the other team is completely destroying mine.  Close games?  Ha!  Everyone fighting their hardest to keep themselves and their team-mates going to achieve victory?  No.  More like, one team gets a lead and camps out over the map and picks off anyone that runs by until the score limit is reached.Those RC-XD remote control cars with explosives are EVERYWHERE, always.  Sniping on a cliff?  There's one behind you.  About to take a position?  One in front.  How about tucked away in a corner at the edge of the map, laying prone to take a bite of sandwich?  Yeah, it's there, too.Good:All the reasons for "boosting" in Modern Warfare 2 or playing cheaply and most of the ability to do it have been eliminated.  Since gun customization is largely based on what you want rather than "Get 150 head shots for this camo!" you can spiff up your favorite firearm to your liking, and take down the enemies with it.  I especially like my Ice-camo Enfield with my waving Kirby emblem.  Spamming of explosives has been severely cut down with the loss of One Man Army and Danger Close.  Basically it's just a lot less cheap.The single-player campaign is pretty dynamic.  Missions are varied, action is fast and exciting.  Storyline is a lot more aggressive and feels more involving.  Rather than slide transitions with voice-overs to go from mission-to-mission ala MW2, you're much better set up to why and how the next mission is happening.  However as reviewers have mentioned: your team mates are idiots, and the enemies seem to have instant, perfect aim from any given distance.  Honestly, you can be lining up a sniper rifle on someone many yards away and they'll make solid hits on you with a pistol.Additions like the Crossbow, Ballistic Knife, and Tomahawk are fun to play with when you get sick of blasting away all the time.  Though to be fair, the Tomahawk is just a re-skinned Throwing Knife.All in all, I really see Black Ops as just a less cheap version of MW2 with different equipment and a better story.  But that's fine.  I played that game for an obscene amount of hours.One final note to parents considering buying this game for their kids this Christmas: you probably shouldn't.  There are a few quite graphic acts of violence throughout the single player campaign.  One notable incident is of the player character sawing through the neck of a Viet Cong soldier with the serrated back of a combat knife.  I know Vietnam was supposed to be an especially grim, unforgiving, and tragic war--and that act (along with the general feel of the Vietnam missions)--sets that up well, but it's not for kids.  Seriously, there's an MA rating on the box for a reason.  It's for mature gamers.
